metadata.title: Quaternary magnetic BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/Fe3O4 nano-junction for visible light and solar powered degradation of sulfamethoxazole from aqueous environment

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
Quaternary magnetic BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/Fe3O4 nano-junction for visible light and solar powered degradation of sulfamethoxazole from aqueous environment
Ajay Kumara, Amit Kumara,⁎, Gaurav Sharmaa, Ala'a H. Al-Muhtasebb, Mu. Naushadc, Ayman A. Ghfarc, Florian J. Stadlerd
a School of Chemistry, Shoolini University, Solan, Himachal Pradesh 173229, India b Department of Petroleum and Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Muscat, Oman c Department of Chemistry, College of Science, Building #5, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia d College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Polymer Science and Technology, Guangdong Research Center for Interfacial Engineering of Functional Materials, Nanshan District Key Laboratory for Biopolymers and Safety Evaluation, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, PR China
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Sulfamethoxazole Hetero-junction Cyto-toxicity Photo-degradation g-C3N4 Visible light
A B S T R A C T
Novel magnetic quaternary BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/Fe3O4 (BGC-F) nano-heterojunction with excellent photocatalytic activity was prepared by facile co-precipitation method. The visible photodegradation activity of the junction was analyzed for sulfamethoxazole (SME) as target pollutant. BGC-F with a dosage of 0.2 g L−1 exhibits high photocatalytic activity with 99.5% of SME (100 µM) degraded in 60min under visible (Xe) lamp and 92.1% in 120min under natural sunlight. The activity of quaternary junction was found to be 7.2, 6.8 and 4.2-fold higher as compared to C3N4/BiOCl/Fe3O4, Cu2O/BiOCl/Fe3O4 and Cu2O/BiOCl/C3N4 junctions respectively. Formation of an effective p-n-p junction (BiOCl-C3N4-Cu2O) leads to shifting of energy bands and rising of an inbuilt electric field and charge separation. The effect of parameters as pH, catalysts loading amount, NO3− and HCO3− have been studied. The %O2− and %OH was found to be major reactive species identified by scavenging experiments and the band gap structure analysis The results for mineralization were analyzed in terms of Liquid chromatography-mass spectroscopy (LC-MS), total organic carbon (TOC) removal and chemical oxygen demand (COD). 41.6% of TOC was removed in 3 h experiment under Xe lamp exposure. The drug degradation was also confirmed by testing activity on E. coli and cyto-toxicity on human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL). Only 2.1 mm zone of inhibition was observed for E. coli in case of exposure to SME degraded products while for pure SME it was 18.1 mm hinting complete mineralization. In addition 99% cell viability was observed for PBL cells

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Innovations in visible assisted photo-degradation of noxious organic pollutants is being considerably needed for practical environmental detoxification [1,2]. The insolent industrialization has led to discharge of untreated wastes from textile, pharmaceuticals, pesticides and cosmetics industries with deteriorating threats to flora and fauna [3–5]. Antibiotics are widely used for disease prevention in humans and animals and are one of most important part of pharmaceutical industry. However when they are released into aquatic environment, they become threat to aquatic life and environment because they eventually increase the drug resistance in pathogens [6]. Sulfamethoxazole (SME) is a broad spectrum antibiotic and used for both human as well as in animals to treat variety of infectious diseases [7–9]. SME has been documented to survive in the aquatic environment which comes from excretory waste as well as from pharmaceutical effluent [9,10]. Among various organic pollutants, antibiotics are challenging to remove via traditional methods as biological, chemical and adsorption. Many methods have been utilized for SME removal from real and simulated waste water systems like ozonation [11,12], adsorption [13], flocculation [14], membrane separation [15], biological treatment [16], electrolysis [17] and coagulation [18].
SME which is polar has been frequently detected in surface water as well as in drinking water in a concentration range of 60–150 ng L−1 and 10–12 ng L−1 respectively [19,20]. Thus mineralization of SME from water is indispensable to screen human and ecological health from its adverse effects. SME belongs to sulphonamides which can be bio-degraded but the process is to slow to be used for practical treatment. Other techniques are also not successful in removal of SME because of its low concentration in water and bio-refractory property. In addition many techniques are highly costly, slow and may not lead to complete mineralization for low concentration persistent pollutants. Advanced oxidation processes (heterogenous photocatalysis) have proven to be an efficient technique because of high degradation, greener approach, cost-effectiveness, lower toxicity, and ease of performance [2].
Recently, visible light driven heterogeneous photocatalysis has attracted research community owing to its green and low cost facets in the various fields such as environmental remediation, splitting of H2O to hydrogen, CO2 conversion to fuels etc. [21,22]. The heterostructure of different materials such as bismuth oxyhalide (BiOX, X=Cl, Br, I)),
transition metal oxides (MO, M=Zn, Ti, Cu, Fe, Mn) have been extensively investigated [23,24]. BiOCl with indirect band gap 3.2–3.6 eV, has been studied by many researchers owing to its good biocompatibility, double layered structure and high chemical stability [25]. However, wide energy band gap limits its use for large practical applications as it performs in UV region.
The p-type semiconductor Cu2O with properties such as excellent visible light response owing to its direct band gap 2.0–2.4 eV, natural abundance and non-toxic nature make it a propitious material for photocatalysis [26]. When Cu2O undergoes photo-illumination the excited e−/h+ pairs are not efficiently separated leading to fast recombination rate which limits its photo activity and this hitch needs to be improved [27].
Recently, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) a metal free polymeric photocatalysts has been extensively used because of its unique merits like low band gap, inertness to chemical and thermal attacks, 2-D structure, eco-friendly nature and abundance of its precursor material [28,29]. g-C3N4 has a high degree of condensation and with a heptazine ring structure it shows good physicochemical properties and a medium range band gap [30]. Thus it has been used in heterogeneous catalysis, pollutant degradation, oxygen reduction reactions and water splitting [31,32]. However, it also suffers from low quantum yield because of high charge recombination rate of its photogenerated e−/h+ pairs, which might hinder the overall photo activity [33].
Furthermore, the popular photocatalysts suffer from drawbacks as ease of separation, lower visible absorption, low surface area and high recombination [34]. This limitation is mainly associated with singlecomponent photocatalysts which can be overcome by fabricating the heterojunction which not only improves the photo-activity but also decreases the e−/h+ pair charge recombination rate significantly [35,36]. Recently various novel carbon nitride based heterojunctions as g-C3N4/CuCr2O4 [37], BiOBr/Iron oxides [38], coal char/g-C3N4/RGO [39], g-C3N4/Fe3O4/Ag/Ag2SO3 [40], g-C3N4/Fe3O4/AgI/Bi2S3 [41], BiOBr/BiOI/Fe3O4 [42] have been utilized for photodegradation of aquatic pollutants. Since current waste water treatment technologies and materials are insufficient in degradation of pharamaceuticals as SME, it is important to design responsive materials which can utilize the existing advanced oxidation processes in a rational manner. Hence a systematic experimental study has been made in this laboratory scale work to utilize quaternary nano-photocatalyst BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/
Fe3O4 (BGC-F) for visible powered and solar induced degradation of SME. The mineralization and practical applicability has been ascertained by TOC/COD, LC-MS, bactericidal activity and cyto-toxicity on human blood cells. The importance of the work lies in the fact that
utilizing popular semiconductors, and highly effective and facile p-n-p junction coupled with Fe3O4 (BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/Fe3O4) was prepared for visible assisted and natural sunlight powered degradation of SME antibiotic.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (BiNO3·5H2O), potassium chloride (KCl), thiourea, sodium hydroxide, ethylene glycol, nitric acid, copper sulphate pentahydrate (CuSO4·5H2O), ethanol, ferric chloride (FeCl3) and ferrous chloride (FeCl2) were obtained from Central Drug House (Analytical Reagent grade) and used without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of g-C3N4
sections.text: The g-C3N4 was synthesized by the thermal condensation of urea. Typically 10 g of powdered urea was placed in silica crucible and calcined at 450 °C in an electric kiln (Jupiter Scientific (CS-50b), temperature range up to 1200 °C, accuracy ± 3 °C of set value) for 3 h with a heating rate 10 °C/min. Once the peak temperature is achieved the deammoniation treatment was performed at 500 °C for 2 h. The resulted yellow material was washed with ethanol and dried at 80 °C in an oven (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Model: Gravity Convection, Chamber material: Aluminum, Temperature range: ambient+5 °C to+210 °C).

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of BiOCl/Fe3O4
sections.text: Fe3O4 nanospheres were prepared by co-precipitation of Fe2+ and Fe3+ with NaOH [43]. 100mg of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were dispersed in 50mL of 5mM ethanolic solution of bismuth nitrate. Dilute HNO3 was added drop wise to the reaction mixture with vigorously stirring. 50mL of KCl (2mM) solution was then added followed by sonication for 1 h (Ultrasonic Frequency: 42,000 Hz, timer: Digital timer with 5 cycles, Tank Material: Stainless Steel SUS304, Tank Capacity: 2500mL) and stirring at 85 °C for 2 h. Finally the grey precipitates were separated and washed with a mixture of ethanol/deionized water. Then the product was dried in a oven at 60 °C for 8 h.

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of BiOCl/ Fe3O4/Cu2O@g-C3N4 (BGC-F)
sections.text: 200mg of BiOCl/Fe3O4 and 100mg of g-C3N4 was dispersed in distilled water. To this solution 100mL of of CuSO4·5H2O (10mM) and 50mmol of Sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS) was added. The contents were vigorously stirred for 1 h followed by 30min sonication. After sonication, 10mL of 0.5M solution of NaOH was added drop wise. 10mL of 0.1 M ascorbic acid was then added to the resultant blue solution. The reaction mixture was then continuously stirred for another 1 h at room temperature. Finally the product was separated by centrifuge, thoroughly washed with ethanol/water mixture and dried at 80 °C in an electric oven followed by sintering at 200 °C for 2 h. Fig. 1 shows the graphical representation of synthetic route for BGC-F junction.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization
sections.text:
The FTIR spectrum of photocatalyst was obtained in the transmission mode between 4000 and 400 cm−1. X-ray diffraction (XRD, analysis was carried out with a Rigaku X ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The specific surface area was measured using N2 sorption by
a NOVA 1200 analyzer and calculated using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was done using PHI 5000 Versa Probe spectrometer (ULVAC-PHI, Japan) with monochromatized Al Ka radiation and binding energy positions were obtained using Kratos Axis Ultra DLD instrument using a monochromated Al Kα irradiation. The ultraviolet–visible spectra (UV–vis) were recorded using a Shimadzu 2202 double beam spectrophotometer. Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was performed using a florescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi, F-4600). The surface morphology of photocatalysts was analyzed using Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with H-7500 (JEM-1230 HC, JPN). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging was done using a JEOL-2011 TEM instrument.

sections.heading: 2.6. Optical studies
sections.text:
A suspension of photocatalyst (10mg) was prepared in 20mL ethanol and ultrasonicated for 1 h. The UV–visible spectrum was recorded using a double-beam spectrophotometer. The band gaps were then computed by Tauc relation [43].

sections.heading: 2.7. Point of zero charge/photoelectrochemical response analysis
sections.text:
For determination of point of zero charge (pzc), 100mg BGC-F was dispersed in 50mL of aqueous 0.1 M NaCl. The pH was varied by addition of acid and alkali. The point zero charge (pzc) is determined by following equation:
= − + −− + σ F C C C C A ( ) { }A B OH H
(4)
Where σ is the surface charge density, F is the Faraday constant. CH+ and COH− represent the equilibrium concentration of H+ and OH− ions on the surface. Similarly CA and CB represent the concentration of strong acid and base. σ is then plotted against pH. The pH at which surface charge density becomes zero is referred to as pzc.
The photoelectrochemical property of BGC-F, g-C3N4, BiOCl and Cu2O was investigated. The composite electrode was prepared using indium-tin oxide (ITO) as substrate to form BGC-F/ITO. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then carried for the photocatalysts with 0.05M Na2SO4 under the open-circuit potential and visible light. The AC voltage amplitude was 5.0 mV with frequency ranging from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz.

sections.heading: 2.8. Photo-degradation of sulfamethoxazole (SME)
sections.text:
The photocatalytic potential of BGC-F was investigated for the degradation of antibiotic SME in water under artificial visible and natural sunlight illumination. An 800W xenon lamp which was positioned in the cylindrical quartz arrangement was used as light source. Detailed experiments were made under Xe lamp source. The temperature was kept constant by water circulation and 400 nm was kept cut-off for providing visible spectrum. After studying all the parameters, degradation of SME in presence of BGC-F was done under natural solar light. The In a typical procedure, BGC-F (0.2 g/L) was suspended in 100mL aqueous SME solution (100 µM) followed by stirring in dark for 30min for adsorption-desorption equilibrium. The resulted suspension was then exposed to sunlight for 90min in a glass photocatalytic reactor. The concentration of SME was determined after regular intervals of time by high performance liquid chromatography (Agilent 1100 series HPLC) employing a C-18 column (5 μm, 4.6mm×150mm) and a diode array detector set at 267 nm. A 60:40 water (acidic) and acetonitrile mixture was used as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1mL/ min. 33% v/v methanol was applied as an isocratic run with a constant flow rate of 0.75mL/min. The absorbance was also recorded using double beam spectrophotometer at 267 nm. The effect of radical scavengers, nitrate ions and bicarbonate ions on photodegradation of SME was also studied.
Total organic carbon was determined by a TOC analyzer (shimadzu, TOC-L) equipped with Shimadzu auto sampler. The limit of detection (LOD) was 0.5 mg/L. Chemical oxygen demand (COD) was estimated by Chemetrics low range (10–150mg/L) COD vials. The degradation pathways were determined by detecting intermediates with a LC-TOF
Mass spectrometer with a electrospray ionization (ESI) and C18 column (150mm×2mm) (30:70 v/v methanol: water as mobile phase; 2% formic acid; injection volume 20 µl).

sections.heading: 2.9. Toxicity and cyto-toxicity analysis
sections.text:
The toxicity of SME and degraded products on E. coli (MTCC 739) was tested by disk diffusion method. Nutrient (Muller Hinton) broth was inoculated with test strains and incubated at 37 °C for overnight (turbidity adjusted to 0.5 McFarland standards). Sterilized swabs were dipped in standardized bacterial suspension with inoculum size of 3.5× 105 cfu/ml (Colony forming Units). Muller Hinton agar plates were prepared and inoculated. The discs were soaked into the pure SME (100 µM) and solution containing degraded products (obtained after 90min degradation in presence of BGC-F). The plates loaded with discs were incubated 37 °C for 72 h. The plates were taken out and zones of inhibition (ZOI) were measured.
The cyto-toxicity of the BGC-F treated SME contaminated water on Human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) (Hi Media) was tested by MTT assay. The PBL cells were cultured in 10% RPMI-1640 medium and incubated overnight in 37 °C. 10 µl MTT was added into well (96 well plate) for generating formazan and again incubated for 4 h. The crystal was then dissolved in 100 µl DMSO. The optical density was then measured using microplate reader (595 nm). The percent viability was then calculated.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 2 (a) shows the diffractogram of BGC-F, the pattern shows the characteristics diffraction peaks for tetragonal BiOCl, cubic Cu2O, cubic
spinel Fe3O4 and hexagonal g-C3N4 which was labeled as ♦,▲, ♥ and ♣ respectively. The diffraction peaks for BiOCl appeared at 2θ values 11.80°, 25.74°, 32.34°, 33.36°, 40.91°, 46.62° and 49.31° which corresponds to the (0 0 1), (1 0 1), (1 1 0), (1 0 2), (1 1 2), (1 1 2), (2 2 0) and (1 1 3) (JCPDS card No. 06-02490) [44]. The peaks for Cu2O and Fe3O4 appeared at 2θ values 36.41°, 42.10°, 52.22°, 60.94°, 77.74° corresponding to the (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (2 1 1), (2 2 0), (2 2 2) planes and are in well agreement with JCPDS file 05-0667 [45]. For Fe3O4 the 2θ values 31.61°, 35.52°, 45.47°, 54.20°, 58.61° are for 62.63° (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) diffraction planes corresponding to JCPDS card 65-3107 [46]. The peaks at 27.21° can be indexed to (0 0 2) plane of graphitic phase of C3N4 (JCPDS card 87-1526) [47].
The average crystallite size of the BGC-F is 27.32 nm.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. FTIR analysis
sections.text: Fig. 2(b) represents the FTIR spectrum of BGC-F. The peaks around 3200, 1250, 1650, and 810 cm−1 are characteristic of g-C3N4. The broad peak at 3150 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibration of NeH group, the peaks at 1555, 1240 and 1330 cm−1 may be assigned to stretching vibrations of CeN heterocycles while a principle sharp peak at 810 cm−1 appeared for stretching mode of triazine unit [48,49]. Furthermore, the absorption bands at 506, 539, and 636 cm−1 correspond to stretching of BieO, FeeO, and CueO in Fe3O4 [50], Cu2O [51] and BiOCl [52]. This confirmed the formation of BGC-F nano heterojunction.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM) and Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 2(c) shows the M-H curve of BGC-F obtained from VSM studies. The photocatalyst is ferromagnetic with low coercivity and a saturation magnetization of 26 emu/g. The magnetization is quite lower than that of pure Fe3O4 as quoted in literature but high enough for magnetic separation from aqueous medium through a magnet. Fig. 2(d)
represents the N2 adsorption-desorption plots for BGC-F. The quaternary junction exhibits a type-IV adsorption isotherm which is because of mesoporous nature of material. The specific surface area is 65 m2/g with pore size 2–11 nm and pore volume 0.032 cm3 g−1. The surface area of g-C3N4 is higher in general due to its porous structure. However the surface area may decrease due to blocking of mesopores by nanoparticles. But a decent surface area of 65m2/g provides better exposure and higher adsorption potential.

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Optical studies
sections.text:
The Tauc plots are represented in Fig. 3(a). The optical band gap of BGC-F is 2.58 eV which lies in visible region. The band gap parameters are listed in Table 1. The UV–Vis DRS spectra of BiOCl, Fe3O4, Cu2O, gC3N4 and BGC-F are given in Fig. 3(b). It is clear from the spectra that there is a red shift in case of BGC-F when compared to individual semiconductors. As we know the photocatalytic efficacy is related to the light absorption potential of the material [53]. From the Fig. 3(b) it is revealed that the BiOCl, Cu2O, Fe3O4 and g-C3N4 showed a light absorption edge at about 380, 620, 470 and 460 nm which correspond to band gap energies 3.02, 2.23, 2.67 and 2.62 eV respectively. The absorption edge of quaternary BGC-F substantially shifted to the pure
visible region with increased absorption intensity. This may be ascribed to successful formation of hetero junction between the employed photocatalysts which not only expands the absorption spectrum but also reduces the charge recombination rate which is essential for photoactivity [54]. Fig. 3(c) depicts the PL spectrum of respective photocatalysts which suggests that sole BiOCl, Cu2O, Fe3O4 and g-C3N4 shows high intensity of PL emission. The intensity is also less for ternary junctions as Cu2O/BiOCl/Fe3O4, g-C3N4/BiOCl/Fe3O4 and g-C3N4/ BiOCl/Fe3O4. But in case of BGC-F the curve flattens completely which is due to increased life time of e−/h+ pair recombination. The photoluminescence is induced by the recombination of holes and electrons. A lower PL shows lower recombination. In the visible light range, g-C3N4 exhibits an emission peak at about 450 nm, which is in accordance with the band gap. The emission peaks for Fe3O4, BiOCl, g-C3N4 and Cu2O vanish in the PL spectrum of BGC-F indicating a highly reduced recombination.
Fig. 4(a) shows the graphical representation of the BGC-F semiconductor heterojunction. The conduction band edge of Cu2O (−0.295 eV) and BiOCl (0.62 eV) lies below that of g-C3N4 (−1.08 eV). This can lead to migration of electrons from g-C3N4 to BiOCl and Cu2O. In addition the electrons too migrate to Fermi level of Fe3O4. In a
similar manner, the flow of holes should take place from VB of Cu2O (1.93 eV) and BiOCl (3.66 eV) to VB of g-C3N4 (1.54 eV).
For p and n-type semiconductors, the Fermi levels are close to valence band and conduction band, respectively [55]. However on the formation of a p-n-p heterojunction (on contact), the shifting of levels
takes place as represented in Fig. 4(b). The energy bands of BiOCl and Cu2O (p-type semiconductors) shift upwards along its Fermi level [56]. Similarly the energy bands of g-C3N4 (n-type) shift downwards along the Fermi energy level. In an equilibrium condition there is a development of −ve charge along BiOCl and Cu2O. It is clear from Fig. 4(b)
that there is now a transition of electrons from BiOCl and Cu2O to gC3N4 which was thermodynamically not possible if p-n-p junction would not have formed. Thermodynamically the first generation of electrons take place in Cu2O due to lowest band gap and because of
favorable band edge position the vectorial charge transfer takes place. Also electrons get transferred from Cu2O into BiOCl due to favorable band positions. A positive charge is built along g-C3N4 due to shifting and favors the electron flow. An intrinsic electric field is developed in absence of exposure which is represented in Fig. 4(c). The formation of electric filed due to migration between p-type and n-type semiconductors leads to migration of photogenerated carriers. On light irradiation this intrinsic field pushes the charge carriers to flow and reduce the recombination. The Fermi levels of BiOCl, g-C3N4 and Cu2O have aligned under thermodynamic equilibrium conditions as seen in Fig. 4(c).

sections.heading: 3.1.5. pzc and EIS analysis
sections.text:
The surface charge density vs pH plot for BGC-F is given in Fig. 5(a). The point of zero charge was found to be 7.2 for BGC-F. This shows that the surface of photocatalyst is negative above pH = 7.2 and positive below 7.2.
EIS spectra for BGC-F, g-C3N4, BiOCl and Cu2O are given in Fig. 5(b). The BGC-F electrode reaches a steady state when compared to BiOCl, g-C3N4, Cu2O. BGC-F has a lower charge transfer resistance and
has a small Nyquist semicircle. This shows that BGC-F has a better conductivity and a higher separation of charge carriers [57]. This is also supported by the PL spectra.

sections.heading: 3.1.6. SEM/EDX analysis
sections.text: Fig. 6(a) shows the low resolution image of BGC-F photocatalyst. The BiOCl, Cu2O and Fe3O4 nanoparticles are dispersed over the g-C3N4 sheets. g- C3N4 shows aggregated morphology with a stacking structure having rough surface due to the thermal polycondensation. High resolution micrograph (Fig. 6b and c) shows flower shaped BiOCl, spherical Fe3O4 and cubical Cu2O nanoparticles in interaction with porous sheets of g-C3N4. The interface showing the formation of junction with particles of three moieties with g-C3N4 is represented in Fig. 6(d).

sections.heading: 3.1.7. TEM analysis
sections.text: Fig. 7(a) and (b) show the low resolution TEM images of BGC-F photocatalyst. The graphitic carbon nitride sheets can be seen with Cu2O, BiOCl and Fe3O4 nanoparticles spread into the matrix. The stacking structure of carbon nitride as seen in SEM images is also visible in TEM images. Fig. 7(b) shows the interface of the junction with shapes of the particles marked. Fig. 7(c) and (d) show Cu2O, BiOCl and Fe3O4 nanoparticles deposited over the g-C3N4 sheet. Fig. 7(e) shows the HRTEM image of BGC-F showing lattice fringes. The SAED pattern (Fig. 7f) represents the high crystallinity of the photocatalyst. The particle size lies between 20 and 30 nm which is also supported by XRD results.

sections.heading: 3.1.8. XPS analysis
sections.text:
The chemical composition of BGC-F was analyzed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 8(a) shows the deconvoluted Bi 4f spectrum. The two peaks at 163.56 and 158.26 which are ascribed to Bi 4f 5/2 and Bi 4f 7/2of Bi3+ of BieO bond [58] respectively.
The Cl 2p spectrum (Fig. 8b) shows fitted peaks at 197.6 and 199.5 eV which correspond to Cl 2p3/2 and Cl 2p1/2 regions of BiOCl respectively [59].
The high resolution Cu2p spectrum (Fig. 8c) shows two deconvoluted peaks at 932.2 eV and 950.93 eV for Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 respectively. This confirms the formation of Cu2O (Cu+ state). The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 8d) shows two peaks at 529.4 & 531.0 eV refereeing to two types of oxygen attributed to oxides and the OH groups. The deconvoluted N1s spectrum (Fig. 8e) shows three deconvoluted peaks at 397.7, 398.3 and 400.1 eV corresponding to sp2 hybridized nitrogen, sp3 NeC and CeNH respectively [2]. The shift for N 1 s from literature values may be due to the change in chemical environment of N in composite. Fig. 8(f) shows the C1s spectrum with peaks at 282.91 eV and 284.9 eV referring to sp2 hybridized carbon of aromatic ring and C bonded to N respectively. The peaks located at about 712.7 eV and 724.9 eV are for Fe 2p3/2 & Fe 2p1/2 respectively as given in Fig. 8(g) which also refers to Iron (III) oxidation state.

sections.heading: 3.2. Photocatalytic degradation of SME under visible light (Xe Lamp)
sections.text:
Sulfamethoxazole as an antibiotic has been used for treatment of urinary infections and bronchitis. But its discharge leads to environmental issues and hazards to flora and fauna.
The photocatalytic potential of quaternary photocatalyst BGC-F has been evaluated by the degradation of SME as a targeted pollutant. Fig. 9(a) shows the degradation of SME in presence of BGC-F and single/binary/ternary photocatalysts as a function of time.99.5% of SME was degraded in 60min by BGC-F.
The order of SME degradation is: BGC-F (99.5%) > Cu2O/BiOCl/g-C3N4 (85.3%) > Cu2O/BiOCl/ Fe3O4 (83.8%) > g-C3N4/BiOCl/Fe3O4 (80.7%) > BiOCl/g-C3N4 (63.5%) > Cu2O/BiOCl (59.4%) > Cu2O/g-C3N4 (57.8%) > g-C3N4 (42.3%) > Cu2O (39.4%) > BiOCl (36.8%).
The plain photolysis of SME under visible light (Fig. 9b) without any photocatalyst shows a degradation of mere 4% in 60min. The overall degradation follows pseudo first order kinetics and results are represented in Fig. 9(c) and the rate constants are listed in Table 2. The apparent rate constant (k1) for BGC-F is 0.0543min−1 with half life of 12.76min. However the rate constant falls for other catalysts and is as low as 0.0079min−1 for single BiOCl. The reaction is manifolds fast as compared to single, binary and ternary photocatalysts. As discussed in optical section the optical band gap of BGC-F is low which facilitates the absorption in visible region which forms major part of the solar spectrum. The formation of an effective p-n-p heterojunction with facilitation of movement of charge carriers by Fe3O4 leads to decreases recombination. This is also confirmed by PL and EIS results. When the semiconductor is exposed to light source corresponding to its optical band gap electron-hole pairs are generated which leads to formation of reactive oxygen species (%OH, %O2−, %OOH, H2O2 etc.) via series of reactions (Scheme 1). The hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radical anions attack the conjugation in the drug molecule leading to the degradation and mineralization thereof (Scheme 2).
The electrons and holes can recombine on the surface and also in the bulk after diffusion (into shallow and deep water) in a time of few nanoseconds or picoseconds. This is represented in scheme 2. But they can be separated if an intrinsic electric filed is built along the surface, so that they can be transferred to the adsorbed molecules. The charge separation & e-h recombination processes take place continuously and are often competitive. Hence the dynamics of the separation and recombination has a manifest effect on the photocatalytic activity.
BGC-F has an excellent photocatalytic activity in visible region owing to superior ability for the photo absorption in the visible region, high electron/hole pair charge separation and transfer at interface of heterojunction. The positions of potential band edges of a heterojunction play an important role for the generation of different reactive oxygen species. When BGC-F undergoes solar irradiation the electron and holes from its counterparts BiOCl, Cu2O, g-C3N4 and Fe3O4 get excited from their valence and conduction bands respectively. The ECB of g-C3N4 is −1.08 eV which is more negative as compared to ECB of Cu2O (−0.295 eV) and BiOCl (0.62 eV). The respective energy potential is quite enough to react the electrons with molecular oxygen to generate superoxide radical Eo(O2/%O−2 )=−0.33 eV vs NHE [60]. Similarly the holes are generated at VB of g-C3N4 (1.54 eV), BiOCl (3.66 eV) and Cu2O (1.93 eV). This potential is high enough for the photochemical oxidation of H2O or −OH to %OH radical (+2.4 eV vs. NHE) [61]. As a result of which all these photogenerated reactive species take part in the degradation of pollutant. On effective contact p-n-p heterojunction is formed the ascent and descent of bands leads to shifting of band edges. In that condition the electrons flow from CB of Cu2O and BiOCl vectorially to CB of g-C3N4 which was earlier not feasible. The migration of holes due to optimum band gap of the semiconductors avoids the recombination. Fe3O4 possess ECB= 1.21 eV and EVB=1.35 eV which make it as a bridge in transfer of electrons and sink as well. The photoexcited e− and h+ get overcrowded at the
surface and subsequently converts Fe3+ to Fe2+ ion which reacts with adsorbed oxygen and water molecule to generate reactive species [62]. Also due to charge transfer the visible absorption increases which is also supported by PL, EIS and photocurrent response analysis
When compared to binary, ternary and single photocatalysts, it is observed that Cu2O/BiOCl/g-C3N4 performs better than Cu2O/BiOCl/ Fe3O4 because there is better charge movement in case of g-C3N4 as compared to Fe3O4 as latter only behaves as sink for electrons. BiOCl scores poorest in terms of photocatalytic activity because of higher band gap and poor absorbance in visible region.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effect of pH on photodegradation of SME
sections.text:
SME is an antibiotic drug and all the drugs are very sensitive to pH due to the presence of acidic or basic functionalities. Their ionization state is controlled by both acidic and basic pH solution. SME exhibits a zwitter ion structure with two pKa values: pKa1= 1.8, pKa2= 5.6; [63] which implies that when pH≤ 1.6 the cationic form (SME+) is dominating and when pH≥ 5.7 the anionic form (SME−) is dominating [64]. The SME molecule is primarily neutral in pH range 1.8–5.6. Thus working pH and pzc of photocatalyst for SME plays a crucial role in the photodegradation process. The working pH in this case is 6.5 and pzc for BGC-F is 7.2. Fig. 9(d) shows the effect of pH on SME degradation in presence of BGC-F. 99.5% SME degradation is achieved in working pH 6.5 with a small decrease at pH=7. As pzc of BGC-F is 7.2, the surface is positively charged at pH 6.5 and that of SME is negative. Thus a strong electrostatic bonding is feasible. Adsorption too plays important role in removal of organic pollutants [65]. The better adsorption of SME
onto photocatalyst leads to better degradation. As electrons and holes are short lived, the adsorbed molecule of pollutant is degraded faster than in bulk because migration or diffusion may lead to annihilation of charge carriers [2]. Extremely acidic and basic pH does not favor the degradation process. At extremely basic medium the surface of both the photocatalyst and SME becomes negative leading to repulsion of moieties [66]. Secondly the strong alkaline condition will generate excess of %OH radical which may block the active site on photocatalysts surface. In highly acidic medium both the drug and BGC-F will be positively charged and thus not favoring the bonding. In addition highly acidic medium may cause leaching of photocatalyst.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Effect of photocatalysts dosage
sections.text: To study the effect of photocatalysts dosage on degradation efficiency, the experiments were performed by varying amount of BGC-F (100–500mg/L). The results are shown in Fig. 10(a). The rate constants for different dosages have been listed in Table 3. The apparent rate constant increases from 0.0051 to 0.585min−1 for dosage variation of 100–400mg/L. At minimum dosage the numbers of available active sites are less for substrate but as soon as the dosage amount increases the active sites increase [67]. But over-dosage of catalyst (500mg/L) leads to agglomeration, turbidity and light scattering which blocks the path of illumination penetration as result of which the efficiency of catalysts decline [68].

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of NO3−, HCO3− ions and H2O2
sections.text:
H2O2 is an important oxidant in the photocatalytic processes. When
H2O2 undergoes irradiation it releases reactive oxygen species. The effect of H2O2 on the photodegradation of SME by BGC-F has been studied at conc. range 0.1–10mM. The rate constants are listed in Table 4.
The apparent rate constant increases from 0.252min−1 (no H2O2) to 0.371min−1 (10mM H2O2). The results show that with the increase in the concentration of H2O2 the degradation of SME was significantly enhanced. H2O2 leads to the generation of more reactive %OH radical either by self-decomposition, photolysis and by accepting the free electrons generated during BGC-F photo reaction [69,70]. Therefore H2O2 scavenges more and more free electrons to provide %OH radical for oxidative degradation of pollutant.
The presence of inorganic ions (NO3− and HCO3−) in a photocatalytic system may affect the efficiency of a photocatalysts. As these are the commonly occurring ions in waste water thus their effect on photocatalysis has been studied.
Fig. 10(c) shows the % degradation of SME at different conc. (0.1–3mM) of HCO3− the rate constant for respective conc. were listed in Table 5. The existence of HCO3− ions in water cause alkalinity and may react with %OH radical to generate %CO3− [38]. However, %OH is very reactive as compared to %CO3− but not selective. In BGC-F system it amplifies the photodegradation of SME. This may be attribute to the fact that %CO3− have adequate reactivity toward amino and sulfur containing moieties [71] and fortunately SME consists both these. Many works have reported the inhibition of rate in presence of bicarbonate ions and some researchers have also found it to be beneficial in degradation. This also depends on the functionality available on the substrate.
When NO3− ions in different concentration were added, the photoefficiency of BGC-F toward degradation was remarkably increased. Table 5 shows the rate constants for different concentration of NO3− ion. Fig. 10(d) represents the reaction kinetics for degradation of SME by BGC-F with varying concentration (0.3 mM–7mM) of NO3− ion. Nitrate ions act as major precursor for %OH radicals under visible light [72]. The rate constant increases from 0.0583min−1 to 0.0751min−1
when nitrate concentration increases from 0.3mM to 3mM. Although an inhibition effect was also observed at 7mM conc. which may be due to the adsorption of NO3− ion competing with SME molecules on the surface of photocatalysts for active sites.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Performance of BGC-F under natural solar light
sections.text:
The photodegradation of SME in presence of BGC-F under natural sunlight was also investigated so as to affirm its use in natural systems and conditions. For natural sunlight exposure: The area of experiment is Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India- 30.9045°N, 77.0967°E in the Himalayan region. The experiments were performed in the month of May with average solar intensity 31×103 ± 100 lx. Fig. 11(a) shows the degradation of SME under natural solar light by BGC-F. In 120min of exposure 92.1% of SME was degraded. The reaction kinetics is shown in Fig. 11(b). The overall degradation process follows first order kinetics with apparent rate constant 0.0352min−1. It is observed that under natural sunlight, a decent degradation is achieved but the degradation time is delayed. In addition the reaction is slower than the Xe lamp irradiation. This is due to the fact the solar spectrum contains UV, IR and visible light. In case of Xe lamp we have a pure visible irradiation. Thus the degradation is affected. Also the solar intensity is not consistent through the day and this may hamper the degradation process. However it is clear that the hetero-junction can be used in real systems too.
3.2.5. Identification of major reactive species by trapping experiment and degradation pathway
Based on above discussion the major reactive species which predominantly involve in the degradation process has been identified by performing trapping experiment. The investigation is done by employing Benzoquinone (BQ) as %O2− scavenger [73], Isopropyl alcohol (IPA) for %OH [60] Tri-Ethanolamine (TEOA) for holes h+ and Potassium dichromate (PD) for electrons e−. Fig. 12(a) shows the effect of scavengers on the degradation efficiency of BGC-F. It was observed that addition of BQ and IPA inhibits the degradation rate sharply, from 99.5% to 14.23 and 7.5% respectively, which indicate that %O2− and %OH are the major active species dominantly involved in photodegradation process. This is also supported by band edges where the production of superoxide radical anions and hydroxyl radicals is feasible. Isopropanol is usually used as a diagnostic tool to determine the mechanism led by %OH (bulk) as IPA is easily oxidized and binds poorly to catalyst in aqueous conditions [74].
Because holes were generated on surface and %OH (IPA scavenges the bulk ones) were generated in the bulk, the photocatalytic oxidation of BPA might occur on the surface of photocatalyst as well as in the bulk solution. However addition of PD do not show high effect on degradation suggesting direct photogenerated electrons do not act as major reactive species. The inhibition in the degradation rate follows the order: BQ > IPA>TEO > PD.
Fig. 12(b) shows the progressive lowering of λmax at 276 nm for SME under visible (Xe lamp) light in presence of BGC-F. This confirms the degradation and mineralization is confirmed by TOC/COD analysis (Fig. 12c) and LC-MS (Fig. 12d). 36.2% of TOC was removed in 3 h of exposure. In addition chemical oxygen demand reduces to 22.4% in 3 h experiment under simulated solar condition (Xe Lamp). This confirms the degradation of drug into simpler moieties. Further the intermediates were analyzed by LC-MS (Fig. 12d) after 1 h of SME photodegradation experiment under Xe lamp (in presence of BGC-F) and listed in Table 6. Reactive species such as %O2−, %OH and h+ attack (from scavenging experiments) the SME molecule as a result of which it undergoes a series of cleavage of CeC, CeN, and CeS bonds. The Photodegradation pathway of SME is quite complicated however, an approach has been attempted to find out the mechanistic route (Scheme 3) on the basis of identified reactive species in LC-MS results. The intermediates at m/z 269.1, 288.3, 215.2 173.1, 99.1 and 109.6 have been detected and are consistent with previous results [75]. The peaks
at m/z 269.1 and 288.3 were ascribed to mono and di-hydroxylated SME.
The detection of C4, C5 and C6 referring to m/z 215.2, 173.1 and 99.1 show that the %OH radicals attack the isoxazole ring and lead to cleavage of SeN bond [8]. Furthermore fragments C8, C5 & C9 show the formation of low weight compound by the continuously attack of ∗OH which ultimately undergoes leads to ring opening and finally mineralizes to low weight acid compounds, water and CO2. Thus it is confirmed that mineralization of SME takes place which is also confirmed by the CO2 emission detected using a Ca(OH)2 test.

sections.heading: 3.3. Reusability and separation
sections.text:
The reusability capacity and separation is an important factor for practical application of a photocatalyst under real systems. Thus the reuse of BGC-F was tested for 5 continuous cycles. Fig. 13(a) shows the magnetic separation of BGC-F from aqueous medium. The degradation percentage decreased from 99.5 to 97.0% after 5th cycle. The results
were presented in Fig. 13(b) which demonstrate that BGC-F possess high reusability and low photo-corrosion. The observed decrease in the degradation capacity may be due to the trapping of intermediates or adsorption of SME on the surface of composite therefore blocking the active sites responsible for degradation.
3.4. Toxicity and cyto-toxicity analysis- confirmation of mineralization
The mineralization and degradation of antibiotic SME was also tested by studying the antibacterial activity of pure drug (100 µM) and the solution obtained after degradation (sample was filtered) on E. coli strains. Fig. 14 shows the results. It is clearly visible the zone of inhibition (ZOI) for pure SME is 18.1 mm. However if we observe the result for treated water sample disc, a ZOI of 2.1mm was obtained. This shows that SME has degraded to simpler molecules which are either non-toxic or less toxic.
In the second set of analysis, the effect of degradation products of SME was studied on human peripheral blood cells. MTT assay was used
Scheme 3.
to investigate the cyto-toxicity. MTT (yellow in colour) is a tetrazolium salt and is reduced by mitochondrial dehydrogenases to form formazan (dark blue in colour). Fig. 14 shows the digital image of PBL cells grown in presence of the degradation products (SME). It is observed that there is no dead cell debris and cells are alive. The bar graph shows the cell viability of untreated cells, cells treated by positive control ConA and the solution containing the degraded products. We observe that 99% of cells are alive in the system containing the solution having degraded products. They are not detrimental to the mitochondria and the cell viability of human blood lymphocytes. This confirms that SME has been degraded to non-toxic or less toxic parts and mineralized. The p-n-p junction sensitized and coupled by Fe3O4 has been found to be simple photoactive material prepared by a facile approach. Many other photocatalysts have been prepared in literature and used for degradation of many organic pollutants. Herein this work magnetically recoverable, highly active junction has been used under artificial visible and natural sunlight for degradation of SME. The experimental part has ended with the toxicity evaluation and cyto-toxicity studies which paves its way to be used in real environment.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, novel magnetic quaternary BiOCl/g-C3N4/Cu2O/Fe3O4 (BGC-F) nano-photocatalyst was successfully fabricated. BGC-F exhibits excellent optical activity owing to its p-n-p arrangement, suitable band gap, improved spectral response and higher charge separation The PL studies and EIS analysis show a high separation of charge carriers which is due to an intrinsic electric field (n-p-n junction) and migration. The catalyst has been used to photodegrade sulfamethoxazole under simulated and real solar light. In 60min of Xe lamp exposure 99.5% of SME was degraded which decreased to 92.1% in 120min under natural sunlight. A comparison has also been made between various single, binary and ternary photocatalyst combinations out of BiOCl, g-C3N4, Cu2O and Fe3O4. The quenching studies reveal that %O2− and %OH radicals as main reactive species. According to LC-MS different degradation pathways have been proposed. The TOC/COD and bactericidal activity on E. coli confirms the degradation and mineralization of SME. In addition the cyto-toxicity on human PBL cells shows that the treated water has low or negligible toxicity. This study could inspire for other opportunities to design semiconductor hetero-junctions and interface engineering rationally for efficient photocatalytic applications
Fig. 13. (a) Magnetic separation of BGC-F (b) Reusability studies of BGC-F for photodegradation of SME.
under real systems.
